awd_titl_txt: Creating Curriculum and Community to Support a Diverse, High-Quality STEM Educator Pipeline for Colorado
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to serve the national need for more K-12 teachers with strong backgrounds in STEM. In line with the nation, Colorado has an acute need for STEM teachers who are prepared to teach a diversity K-12 students. This project intends to build capacity for a program of study that could result in a more skilled STEM teacher workforce that is more representative of the K-12 student population in Colorado. The project, through partnerships with K-12 schools, will build capacity for the recruitment and education of STEM majors interested in teaching mathematics and science. Meeting this goal will help fill the need for scientific and technical professionals throughout the greater Denver area, Colorado, and the nation.

This project at Colorado Christian University (CCU) includes partnerships with Alameda International Jr./Sr. High School and Littleton High School. Project goals include: (1) Revise CCU STEM and education curricula to create and widen pathways for STEM majors to become prepared teachers; (2) Generate a strong STEM education community, particularly for Hispanic students; and (3) Increase recruitment capacity through expanding K-12 school partnerships. Knowledge gained from this project will be used to develop a Noyce Track 1 Scholarships and Stipends proposal. Collectively, these projects could contribute to understanding ways in which small, faith-based, liberal arts colleges can attract STEM majors for training in secondary STEM education. The project will investigate the effects of building infrastructure and processes that engage and support STEM majors, support new STEM teachers, and strengthen culturally and linguistically responsive pedagogical content. CCU will disseminate project evaluation findings to other small, private universities. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the effectiveness and retention of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project at Colorado Christian University (CCU) includes partnerships with Alameda International Jr./Sr. High School and Littleton High School. Project goals include: (1) Revise CCU STEM and education curricula to create and widen pathways for STEM majors to become prepared teachers; (2) Generate a strong STEM education community, particularly for Hispanic students; and (3) Increase recruitment capacity through expanding K-12 school partnerships.

Knowledge gained from this project will be used to develop a Noyce Track 1 Scholarships and Stipends proposal.

The leadership team was flexible, became aware of limitations to full implementation of the awarded proposal, and made changes aligned with the overall vision. The intended Physics and Mathematics core teacher education programs were replaced with Biology since the university?s infrastructure could not sustain the intended program. The Biology curriculum was modified and enhanced to be more culturally responsive; education licensure will be added to the Biology major.

The original Hispanic student group that was formed with support from this Noyce grant was expanded to be more diverse; it is named Unique Voices. Based on feedback from students, this group is very supportive, has a positive climate, and makes good use of student time. Unique Voices provides an atmosphere where students from a variety of backgrounds can freely share their viewpoints, and it includes activities that strengthen participants? resolve to graduate with a Bachelor?s degree. The group, which was initially led by faculty, is being transitioned in spring 2023 to being led by students.

In order to strengthen knowledge of the systematic and structural barriers women and students of color may face in STEM fields, Dr. Renee Lizcano prepared five modules that addressed culturally responsive pedagogy and STEM subjects.  The modules will be used by instructors at Colorado Christian University teaching Education and/or STEM courses in which preservice teachers are enrolled.

CCU STEM Experience workshops were held in  October 2022 and in April 2023. Three CCU students were Assistants who agreed that the experience improved their communication skills and enhanced their ability to be flexible and able to adapt to different circumstances. It was hoped that being part of this workshop would strengthen students' commitment to be science teachers. Two ninth grade students (one male, one female) who completed the participant reaction form agreed that the hands-on experiments in the lab was ?excellent?.

Enthusiasm for attending CCU as a result of participating in the workshop increased for the two students: One student ?from 7 to 9? and a second student from ?3 to 7? (the scale was 1 to 10, 10 very enthusiastic). After the STEM workshop students met with admissions and were provided lunch and given a campus tour.

Project leadership has been actively involved in reaching out to partner schools and surrounding communities. Groundwork for full implementation of the community outreach component has been completed with lessons-learned being used to inform future activities. For a fall 2023 STEM workshop, the CCU Noyce team is planning to try a weekday event where the schools take a field trip to the CCU campus. This will likely be successful since students will have school transportation, CCU won't have to coordinate with security to unlock buildings, and students will still be able to keep their weekend activities/commitments.

Overall, the project is the first step in providing the infrastructure for developing a pipeline of highly qualified teachers with strong backgrounds in STEM content, as well as training in effective culturally and linguistically responsive pedagogies and providing a large, well-prepared pool of STEM teacher candidates who will teach effectively in local, high-need K-12 schools.
